description:
Quercus lobata, commonly known as the Valley Oak or California White Oak, is a species of oak tree native to California, United States. It is a large, deciduous tree that can grow up to 30 meters (100 feet) in height and has a broad, rounded canopy.

The leaves of Quercus lobata are lobed, with deep sinuses, and can reach up to 20 centimeters (8 inches) in length. The bark is thick, fissured, and gray-brown in color. The acorns produced by the tree are large, up to 5 centimeters (2 inches) long, and can take up to two years to mature.

Quercus lobata is an important component of the oak woodland and savanna ecosystems in California, providing food and habitat for a variety of wildlife species. The tree is also culturally significant to several Native American tribes in the region. Due to habitat loss and other factors, the species is classified as Near Threatened by the IUCN Red List of Threatened Species.
